title: Abstract of Unit 2, Section 2: How Likely Is It?
body: This section, titled 'How Likely Is It?', is part of Unit 2 and spans 7 instructional days. It focuses on the concept of probability, explaining that it quantifies the long-run frequency of chance outcomes. Students will learn to approximate probabilities through both simulations and mathematical calculations. The engagement activity involves analyzing a scene from 'Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead' to discuss coin toss probabilities. Learning objectives cover statistical understanding of independence (S-CP 2), using permutations for inference (S-CP 9), evaluating data-based reports (S-IC 6), designing simulations using RStudio, comparing simulated and actual data, re-randomizing data, and estimating theoretical probabilities from samples. Language objectives include constructing summary statements about probability, using Venn diagrams for compound events, and presenting understanding of simulations. Data will be collected through simulated data in RStudio.

title: Enduring Understandings: Probability and Simulations
body: The core idea is that probability is a measure of how often an event is likely to occur over the long run. This can be determined in two primary ways: by conducting simulations, which mimic the real-world event, or by using mathematical calculations. Both methods help in understanding and quantifying the likelihood of different outcomes.

title: Engagement Activity: Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead Coin Toss Scene
body: The engagement for this unit involves students watching a specific scene from the movie 'Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead'. This scene prompts a discussion about the probability of a coin landing on 'heads' 78 times consecutively. The scene is accessible via a provided YouTube link and embedded video.

title: Learning Objective: Statistical Independence of Events (S-CP 2)
body: A key statistical objective is to understand and determine if two events, A and B, are independent. Independence is formally defined as the probability of both events occurring together being equal to the product of their individual probabilities (P(A and B) = P(A) * P(B)). This understanding will be used to assess the independence of events.

title: Learning Objective: Permutations for Inference (S-CP 9)
body: This objective focuses on the use of permutations, particularly in the context of data science, to perform informal inference. Permutations involve arranging items in different orders and can be applied to data to understand variability and make conclusions about populations based on samples.

title: Learning Objective: Evaluating Data Reports (S-IC 6)
body: Students will develop the ability to critically evaluate reports that are based on data. This involves understanding how data is presented, identifying potential biases or misleading information, and assessing the validity of conclusions drawn from the data.

title: Data Science Objective: Designing Simulation Algorithms
body: In the realm of data science, a key learning objective is to understand how algorithms are developed and utilized to design simulations. This involves learning the logic and steps required to create computational models that mimic real-world processes for the purpose of probability estimation.

title: Applied Computational Thinking: Conducting Simulations in RStudio
body: Using RStudio, students will gain practical skills in designing and executing simulations. This hands-on experience will allow them to create their own simulated scenarios and observe the outcomes, providing a tangible way to explore probability concepts.

title: Applied Computational Thinking: Comparing Simulated and Actual Data
body: A crucial aspect of using simulations is the comparison between the data generated by the simulation and real-world data. Students will learn to use RStudio to perform these comparisons, assessing how well their simulated models represent actual phenomena.

title: Applied Computational Thinking: Re-randomization of Permuted Data
body: This objective focuses on the technique of re-randomization applied to permuted data. Re-randomization is a method used in statistical inference, particularly for hypothesis testing, where data is shuffled randomly to simulate the null distribution.

title: Applied Computational Thinking: Estimating Theoretical Probabilities
body: Students will learn to utilize the results from samples, specifically estimated probabilities derived from these samples, to infer and determine the underlying theoretical probabilities of events. This connects empirical observations to mathematical probability.

title: Real-World Connections: Using Simulations for Expectations
body: The practical application of simulations is emphasized, teaching students how to use them as a tool to determine the expected outcomes or frequencies of various events in real-world scenarios. This bridges the gap between theoretical concepts and practical problem-solving.

title: Language Objective 1: Summarizing Probability Understanding
body: Students will be able to articulate their comprehension of probability by constructing clear and concise summary statements. This objective focuses on the verbal and written expression of statistical concepts learned in the unit.

title: Language Objective 2: Venn Diagrams for Compound Events
body: This objective involves using Venn diagrams as a tool to visually represent and compare compound events and their associated probabilities. Students will practice explaining the relationships between different events using this diagrammatic method.

title: Language Objective 3: Group Presentations on Simulations
body: Students will engage in collaborative group presentations. The purpose of these presentations is to effectively communicate their understanding of how simulations are used to assess probabilities, requiring them to synthesize and share their knowledge with peers.

title: Data Files and Collection Method
body: The primary data used in this section will be simulated data generated within the RStudio environment. This approach allows for controlled experimentation and exploration of probability concepts without relying on pre-existing, real-world datasets for initial learning.
